(42) 79thConclusions,Minute 4.)1. The War Cabinet discussed" the arrangements for theforthcoming Debates in Parliament on the situation in the middle east.It was not certain that Sir John Wardlaw-Milne, M.P., would proceed with his proposal to table a Motion of Censure. If he did' proceed with that proposal, the Labour Party, who would not support a Censure Motion, might table a Motion calling for an enquiry into the conduct of the campaign.The War Cabinet agreed that, in the statement on business thefollowing day, the Lord Privy Seal should announce that, if aCensure Motion were tabled, the Government would give facilitiesfor it to be debated on Wednesday and Thursday, the 1st and2nd July. If such a Motion were not put on the Order Paper, theGovernment would arrange for the Debate to be taken, on the sametwo days, on the Votes of several Departments, including the vote of the Minister of Defence. In either event, there would be a division at the end of the Debate.The Secretary of State for the Colonies informed the WarCabinet that a similar Debate would take place in the House ofLords on Thursday, the 2nd July, on a Motion which had alreadybeen put down by Lord Addison. He did not think that this wouldbe pressed to a Division.The War Cabinet took note of this statement.The Tank 2. (42) 48) on an enquirythe Middle which he had been asked to undertake by the Defence Committee,East. at their Meeting on the 2nd March (D.O. (42) 7th Meeting,Minute 1), into the following questions : (a) Why the Middle East Command had not reported after the battle in June 1941 that the German tanks were armed with a 4^-pdr. gun; and(Jo) What was the cause of the defects disclosed in the Crusadertanks, and why had these not been detected earlier.The War Cabinet-Took note of this Report. The record of the discussion is contained in the Secretary's Standard File of War cabinet conclusions.shipping situation.(PreviousHef erence: 'W.M. (42) 28thConclusions,Minute 2.)3. The War Cabinet were informed that at their meeting that morning the Chiefs of Staff had decided to appoint a small naval staff-Air Staff Committee (on the level of the Assistant Chief ofNaval Staff-Assistant Chief of Air Staff) with the following termsof reference : '' To review and advise the Chiefs of Staff on the generalpolicy for the employment of the Air Force on the basis of the strategy contained in Memorandum W.W./1, which is to be interpreted as requiring our commitments to be met in thefollowing order of priority : (a) Minimum necessary Fighter defence of UnitedKingdom.(b) Minimum necessary allocation for securing our vitalcommunications and interrupting those of theenemy.(c) Maximum possible provision for the offensive, bothdirect and in support of land operations." 97W.M.80 (42).The War Cabinet considered whether, notwithstanding theappointment of this Committee, they would hold a meeting on thefollowing day to consider the Joint Memorandum on the shipping situation submitted by the First Lord of the Admiralty and theMinister of War Transport (W.P. (42) 265).The War Cabinet-(1) Asked that the Report from the Committee appointed bythe Chiefs of Staff should be submitted within a week.(2) Agreed to hold a meeting on the following day, for a pre-liminary review of the shipping situation, at which theJoint Memorandum of the First Lord of the admiralty and the Minister of War Transport would be considered.Great George Street, S.W. 1,June 24, 1942.
